Hi, this is Ben from AMD.   The port is in the early stages of development as you note.  Glad to see this issue since we wanted to make sure the community was aware of our plans and get some early feedback before we get too deep into the port.  Let me provide a little background on the tools and what we'd like to do, and ask a couple questions:

[HIP](https://github.com/ROCm-Developer-Tools/HIP) is an open-source toolkit designed to port CUDA code.  After porting, the code can run on AMD [ROCm](https://rocm.github.io) GPU platform or still on the original CUDA (with same performance).   HIP runtime and C++ language are familiar to CUDA programmers so the porting process is lightweight and does little damage to the original code.   The HIP code is easy to maintain since it is close to CUDA, and provides full C++ support including templates, classes, namespaces, etc.   HIP runtime code, headers, and porting tools are maintained on GitHub  and updated every 2-4 weeks by AMD developers.

AMD is also developing an open-source optimized machine intelligence library called "MIOpen".  This will contain convolution, pooling, and other kernels which have been optimized for AMD GPUs.  The MIOpen host runtime API accepts HIP parameters for things like streams, and also defines Tensor and other structures for memory management.   MIOpen is currently internal but will be open-sourced shortly.

We'd like to use these tools to enable MXNet to run on the ROCm platform.  Overall strategy would be to port the CUDA code to HIP, and add the calls into MIOpen in the appropriate layers so it runs fast.   The MXNet port is being developed in the open [here](https://github.com/ROCmSoftwarePlatform/mxnet).  

One early design question we could use some help on: the port currently replaces the CUDA code with HIP code.  This was an easy way to start since it requires less initial modification to the MXNet make system - we can just port the .cu files and start building.  However, we likely want to instead use a design where the HIP files exist alongside the CUDA ones.  What is best way to add a new HIP target to the MXNet code - where should we put the files, and what make changes are required?  

Thanks!  We look forward to participating in the MXNet community,
-ben

@eldercrow need_top_grad has been set to False.

I checked the backward **Node**s generated, it seems that the problem arises because of an out-of-date understand about how loss layers work. In the code I tried to run, the **SoftmaxOutput** accepts gradient from its top layer, but the **LinearRegressionOutput** dose not. I guess the reason maybe that the argument **out_grad** has been removed from **LinearRegressionOutput**(**grad_scale** seems not able to be dynamically and example-wise changed?) and still works in **SoftmaxOutput**(when **out_grad**=True) in mxnet 0.9.5.

Found this:

https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/v0.10.0/docs/get_started/build_from_source.md

I suggest adding a compilation flag `USE_HIP`. Then in makefile, add the following

```
ifeq ($(USE_HIP), 1)
	CFLAGS += -DMXNET_USE_HIP=1
	LDFLAGS += -lhip  # if there is a libhip.so
endif
```

So now we can switch between hip and cuda in source codes by

```
#if MXNET_USE_HIP == 1
// codes
#endif
```

Also you can modify the CMake building system
On Mon, Jun 5, 2017 at 09:42 Mu Li <notifications@github.com> wrote:

> I suggest adding a compilation flag USE_HIP. Then in makefile, add the
> following
>
> ifeq ($(USE_HIP), 1)
> 	CFLAGS += -DMXNET_USE_CUDNN=1
> 	LDFLAGS += -lhip  # if there is a libhip.so
> endif
>
> So now we can switch between hip and cuda in source codes by
>
> #if MXNET_USE_HIP == 1
> // codes
> #endif

@patricianing 
LocationNet is inspired by PlaNet but it's trained on different dataset, architecture, hyperparams. 
The comparison of these two can be found [here](https://github.com/multimedia-berkeley/tutorials).

Examples in this [tutorial](https://github.com/multimedia-berkeley/tutorials/blob/master/predict_geolocation.ipynb) will give you coordinate geo-tag (latitude, longitude). If you want to get a plaintext place name from this coordinate geo-tag, you can use one of the reverse geocoding services online such as [Google's MAP API](https://developers.google.com/maps/documentation/javascript/examples/geocoding-reverse) or [this one on github](https://github.com/thampiman/reverse-geocoder).

Where do I get `ml.dmlc.mxnet.contrib`? I don't see any JAR artifact that has that `contrib` package!

So, maybe the problem is that the current 0.9.3a JAR artifact `mxnet-core` does not contain the `contrib` package. The files in `scala-package/core/src/main/scala/ml/dmlc/mxnet/contrib/` were added on Apr. 11, whereas the JAR artifact `mxnet-core` 0.9.3a was published on Mar. 26. So, that's why I don't see them, and perhaps that's why my Scala code can't use CTCLoss.

Would it be possible to update the Scala artifacts to 0.10 so that they contain the `contrib` package and and possibly fix this problem?
(I am having multiple problems compiling the mxnet source under OS X, so I can't test whether it's the real root of the problem.)

I benchmarked performance on TX2, and didn't see any significant difference between fp16 and fp32 either.
I built mxnet on TX2 with USE_PASCAL=1 flag and run profiling of resnet 18 example with fp16 and fp32 available from the repository files resnet.py, resnet_fp16.py, respectively.
I use batch size of 20 images and average the results over 50 times. Prior to run with the profiler, I perform a dry run with the same batch size of 20 and number of runs = 5. For profiling I follow the example https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/example/profiler/profiler_executor.py

I get 15.24 ms/frame​ for fp16 and 15.67 ms/frame for fp32
I attach a screen shot of the profiler output for one of the batches in each case.
![profiler-resnet-18-fp16-tx2](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6402251/26806301/f9b9863e-4a04-11e7-91b0-e448e392914a.png)

Secondly, could you run the code through nvprof and post somewhere the result? The command to do it should look something like this:

I run nvprof with resnet.py and resnet_fp16.py with batch size 1 and # runs = 1000 (640x480 images) on Jetson TX1.
resnet.py profile output: https://drive.google.com/open?id=0Bwb8o6lldJgBUGdhQVZXYnFTMjg
resnet_fp16.py profile output: https://drive.google.com/open?id=0Bwb8o6lldJgBSmNJSkdjZXByZ2M

overall it seems that in case of resnet_fp16.py *_fp16_* kernels are called, i.e. maxwell_fp16_scudnn_fp16_128x128_small_nn vs. maxwell_scudnn_128x128_small_nn in case of resnet.py, which is a good sign. However, maxwell_fp16_scudnn_fp16_128x128_small_nn kernel takes 63.5 s in total for all 1000 runs, whereas maxwell_scudnn_128x128_small_nn takes 44.3 s in total.

increasing batch size to 2 results into 28.6 s for maxwell_fp16_scudnn_fp16_128x128_small_nn vs. 39.9 s for maxwell_scudnn_128x128_small_nn, which is encouraging. However, the second most time consuming kernel maxwell_fp16_scudnn_winograd_fp16_128x128_mobile_tile148t_nt takes 21.7 s vs. 14.7 s in case of maxwell_scudnn_winograd_128x128_mobile_tile148t_nt. Thus overall I don't observe any speed-up due to switching to fp16. 

Any ideas?

@szha Ok, I'll try. Besides, I tried to use `nvidia-docker`. Due to poor network speed, I always failed to `make` on my this IBM OpenPower machine (Need to build a specail version for openpower architecture `nvidia-docker`) . :sob:

Unfortunately we are not allowed to provide this data to third parties... **However**, I tried further to figure out what the problem is, and I think the only missing thing for us is a 0.10 release of the mxnet `jni` library.

I was able to compile `mxnet` successfully on an OS X, but only after I changed a couple of things in the build settings while following `docs/get_started/osx_setup.md`.

One of these changes was, unfortunately, that I had to disable OpenCV. This makes my build unusable for our purposes. Another was that I had to change g++ to g++-7, gcc to gcc-7, and linker flags in `scala-package/native/osx-x86_64-cpu/pom.xml` and `scala-package/init-native/osx-x86_64/pom.xml` from `-force_load` to `-Wl,-force_load,` in three places.

The result is a full mxnet/scala package with 0.10.1-SNAPSHOT version that I can now use to load the json file and param file for our trained model that uses CTC Loss. So, indeed if you could just build and publish the latest 0.10 release for scala package with supported platforms (OSX and Linux64), that would fully solve my problem.

In fact, the problem would be fully solved and we would be unblocked if you could just compile the jni library `libmxnet-scala-osx-x86_64-cpu.jnilib` for the 0.10 release on OSX non-gpu. That's the only thing I can't compile correctly so far. (Linux compilation works fine!) I would really appreciate your help since it's probably quite easy for you to compile this.

Is the goal only building the arch for the GPU installed to accelerate the building? I checked the CI build, it still has all arches enabled `-gencode arch=compute_30,code=sm_30 -gencode arch=compute_35,code=sm_35 -gencode arch=compute_50,code=sm_50 -gencode arch=compute_52,code=[sm_52,compute_52] `

First I'm not sure having doc for cloning a particular tag is necessary. People can easily google "git clone a tag" for instructions. Most time people just download the source tar from https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/releases. 

Second, even we want to add the instructions in the document, I don't think we should replace the instructions for building from source. I suggest to only add one sentence that

> You can use `git checkout tags/xxx` to build a particular release. See https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/releases for all releases.

@bhavinthaker the tutorial already explains you should have GPU installed and be compiled with USE_CUDA=1 to run on GPU. I don't think we need to double emphasize it. I'm going to close the PR, but please feel free to reopen it.

It is duplicated to mention that you need to have python installed in every tutorial. We should put it on a single page, such as README.md. Also these tutorials will have other language versions later, we should not sure it is python only.

I feel checking `sys.version_info.major` is not clean. We may use 

```
for key in xx_dict:
   val = xx_dict[key]
```

so that it works on both python2 and python3
@JeanKossaifi can you please have a look at this PR?

I agree most people know `git checkout tags/xxx`. The non-trivial part is updating the submodules correctly (`git submodule update --init --recursive`). 

Google search for "git clone a tag" does not return results that talk about how to update the submodules correctly. 
Given this problem happened with our own DL AMI builds (the builds were not updating the submodules, the script was just doing a `git checkout tags/xxx` which is not sufficient), I don't think this is a trivial thing that everybody gets right. 

Given it is non-trivial and we ourselves have got it wrong before, I suggest we document the steps so that it is easy for people who want to build a particular release. 

@bhavinthaker, @madjam - Thoughts?
